item.title: Andy's prompt writing principles
item.description: One of the more thoughtful resources on Prompt writing principles for flashcards is Andy Matuschak’s How to write good prompts. According to him, prompts should be: Focused Precise Make clear what the prompt is looking for “poorly written prompts require that you also memorize what the prompt is asking” Consistent Tractable Effortful Encoded thoroughly Attributes / tendencies Similarities and differences Parts and wholes Causes and effects Significance and implications .

item.title: Defining Technology
item.description: When we invoke the word “technology”, we’re often implicitly referring to electronics. And while that’s one illustration, it’s far from the word’s main meaning.

item.title: Desirable features for automating flashcard creation
item.description: In attempting to answer: § How can LLMs enhance spaced repetition software? Many different answers arise.This note collects those possibilities: From me § LLMs can help revise and build on existing flashcards LLMs can slowly push the boundaries of what we know LLMs can act as training wheels for users of spaced repetition systems To lay down signposts while reading.
